dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darkness. Silence. After a long beat, we hear movement, confined and contained. We then hear the sound of a man, PAUL CONROY, groaning, making confused attempts at words. We hear his movement; short, abrupt shifting, ending almost immediately with th sound of his body banging against wood. He screams, though it's clear from the sound that his mou is covered by something. After attempting to sit up, he immediately bangs his head against something. It's terribly warm and his breaths are labored. He attempts to move to his left and right, only to find t he is confined on those sides, as well. He frantically shifts about, only to discover, by touch, that he is enca in something. Something is very wrong, and he doesn't need to see to kn that. Finally, we see him, lit by the flame of the Zippo he hol in his hands, which are bound together in front of him wi rope. A rolled-up, dirty rag is tied tightly around his head, stretched across his mouth. Dried blood stains his hair and forehead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see that he is lying in an old fashioned, wooden coffi Nothing more than a few rotted-out planks of wood nailed together. Realizing the same, Paul is struck by an overwhelming, instant panic. With great difficulty, and while still holding the lit Zi Paul removes the muzzle from his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What...? What is this? His words become almost unintelligible as he flails about though fear is understood in his every utterance. He screams aloud, but his voice is captured by the coffin walls. 2.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my God! Help me!! Help me!! He kicks and slams his hands against the top and sides of coffin, all to no avail. His violent movements cause smal grains of sand to trickle in through the space between th sides and top of the coffin, as well as a small gap that exists between one of the coffin's broken wooden planks. Sweat cascades down the side of his neck, dripping from h dampened brow. The heat inside the extremely close confin of the coffin is stifling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somebody help me! Please!! Paul continues with his futile efforts to pry off the top the coffin. The sides, the top, the bottom -- all are too thoroughly reinforced by the force of what surrounds the coffin. Sand. It becomes clear to him that he is buried. He tries his best to calm himself, though he has trouble catching his breath. It takes him some time, but he eventually achieves some semblance of calm. Getting a good look at him for the first time, we see tha Paul is somewhere around 37 years old. Unshaven and physically unremarkable, he embodies the blue-collar Amer everyman. He coughs. The minimal amount of oxygen in the coffin mak it hard for him to breathe. His eyes widen a bit upon seeing an exposed, rusty nail. tries desperately to use the nail to cut through the old, frayed ropes that bind his hands. Doing so is no easy tas The incredibly tight quarters makes his every action near impossible. After a lengthy struggle, the rope snaps. Paul quickly fr his hands. A small victory. Very small. The heat is unbearable. Paul takes off his button-down shirt, leaving him in a T-shirt. His body battles against the walls and the ceiling of the coffin with every move h makes. He tosses his button-down shirt down by his feet. His undershirt is drenched through with sweat. Still trying to calm himself, but having little success i doing so, Paul looks around the coffin. His feet, though only his body-length away, seem miles from him. 3.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at the top of the coffin, and then back at his f With great difficulty, he shifts his body so that his fee are pressed against the top of the coffin. He attempts to use his leg strength to push the top off of him, but it doesn't move even a millimeter. After several failed attempts, and with his legs exhauste Paul drops his feet from the top of the coffin. He lay fo moment in silence, followed by an outburst of crying. Close to his head, on the corner of the floor, we see the another broken plank. A small hole. He closes his cigarette lighter, extinguishing the flame. total darkness, he continues to cry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is this? With his sobbing slowly subsiding, the coffin soon grows eerily silent. The sound of Paul's labored breaths are all we hear, soft under the blanket of absolute darkness. After a beat, the silence is interrupted by a subtle buzz sound. The muted sight of strange, blueish light flickers the coffin, by Paul's feet. He is extremely startled. The buzzing continues, as does the minimal splashing of light. It's coming from underneath his discarded button-d shirt, down near his feet. He lights the Zippo to get a better look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pulling the shirt away, he realizes that what he is heari and seeing is the vibrating ring and display features of older model cell phone. He frantically reaches for it, though the coffin is far t small for him to reposition himself so easily. To his dismay, the phone stops ringing. But, his efforts reach it continue. He uses his feet to search for the pho After some trouble finding it, he eventually locates it. Clamping the phone together between his clasped feet, Pau then painfully angles his body so that he can reach his f with his hands and grab it. He is soon able to reach it. Immediately thereafter, he flips open the phone and puts the receiver in front of hi 4.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see that there is a Text Message waiting for Paul on t phone. However, Paul barely notices. The time on the phone reads 6:12pm. While the numbers and display screen icons are familiar to Americans, all the w are in Arabic. What he does notices is that the phone barely has one bar signal strength. Worse yet, there is only half of the battery life remaining. He tries to remember the Safe Number he was given. With t phone open and ready to be dialed, Paul struggles to reca the information.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, come on. What was it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Getting only two digits into dialing the number, he canno remember much more and closes the phone. He wedges the lit Zippo into sand, which is compacted aga a small hole in the wall of the coffin. Paul reaches into his pants pocket, frantically searching something. He hastily removes a prescription pill bottle a small, metal flask. Both are not what he was looking fo He then reaches to his back pocket and removes his wallet It's empty. His license, his credit cards, his cash and, most importantly at that very moment, a piece of paper wi the Safe Number written on it, are all missing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Where the hell is it? Son of a...Come on!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He screams aloud again, hoping greatly that someone can h him. His frenzied maneuvering puts out the flame of the Zippo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Help me! Please! Somebody help me! His words barely make it pass the coffin walls. With the cell phone still in hand, and laboring to reclai the breath he just expended, Paul turns to desperation. H dials the international code of 001, and then dials 911. A FEMALE 911 OPERATOR answers almost immediately. 5.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 911, please hold. The Female 911 Operator places Paul on hold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! Wait! Paul accidentally bangs the cap of the Zippo against the coffin wall, putting out the flame. She quickly returns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 911. What is your emergency?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 911. What's the problem, sir? Paul is so incredibly panicked that he has trouble remain coherent. After a few sparks, the Zippo is re-lit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm buried. You have to help me. You have to help me, I can't breathe...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm buried in a coffin. Please help me! Send someone to find me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir...slow down. What is your name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul. Paul Conroy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, Mister Conroy. Can you tell me your location?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. I'm in a coffin. I don't know where. I'm scared. Please help me. 6.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're in a coffin?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, it's, like, one of those old, wooden ones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you at a funeral home?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I don't know. No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How are calling me right now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you're buried in a coffin, where are you calling from?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cell phone. There was an old cell phone in the coffin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're calling from your cell phone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. No. It's not mine, but yes, I'm calling from a cell phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There was a cell phone in the coffin when you climbed in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't climb in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did you end up in the coffin, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was put here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the coffin?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Please send help. 7.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you're saying the coffin is buried?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think so. It's...it's hot in here. I can't breathe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know your location, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you, I don't know. Somewhere in Iraq.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Iraq?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. I'm a truck driver, an American. I work for CRT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you a soldier, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Please, please listen to me. I'm a truck driver. I work for CRT. I'm a civilian contractor working in Iraq. We were attacked in Baqubah, they...they...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...shot them. All of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They shot who, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All of the other drivers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you're saying this happened in Iraq? The country?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Please, you have to help me. They gave me a safety number to call, but I had it stored in my wallet and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mister Conroy, this is 911 emergency in Youngstown, Ohio. 8.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ohio?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. I'm not sure exactly how you called here if you're in another country, but if you'd like, I can patch you through to the Sheriff's Department.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sheriff's Department? No...you don't underst...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...forget it. Realizing that his conversation is both lengthy and usele Paul ends the call. He checks the battery life on the pho It still holds steady at two bars. He immediately dials another number, one that he can reca with ease. He again enters the 001 international code before making call. Paul then dials his home phone. It rings several times, s far unanswered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, come on. Pick up. Please. After sitting through the agony of a few more rings, Paul met with the answering machine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The voice of his young son, SHANE, is heard on the answer machine greeting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks for calling the Conroy's. We're not home right now. Please leave a message at the beep. Thanks. At the sound of the Beep, Paul leaves a frenzied, ramblin message.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Linda, honey, it's me. Listen, I need you to contact the National Guard right away. Or the Pentagon. Tell them we were attacked in the Diyala Provence, in Baqubah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They have to find me. Please help me, baby. Please help them find me. Paul hangs up. He dials his wife's cell phone right away. After several rings, her cell phone voice mail picks up. hear the sound of Linda, Paul's wife, on her outgoing message.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, this is Linda. Please leave a message. Thanks and have a great day. The Beep sounds and Paul immediately tears into his voice message.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Linda, it's Paul. I need you to call me right away. This is an absolute emergency. Call the number that comes up on your phone. Call me at that number. If I don't answer, call the Pentagon or the F.B.I. I don't know what the hell is going on, but I'm buried in a box... Hearing himself say those last words gives him pause. The gravity of the situation fully takes hold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I can't breathe in here. Make sure you call me right away. Please, baby, please call me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul ends the call. He nervously looks at the amount of battery life remaining on the phone. Still holding strong two bars. He notices the flickering light of the Zippo. It, too, appears to be using up small amounts of oxygen. He closes the lid, extinguishing the flame. Total darkness. Silence, save for Paul's increasingly hea breaths. He begins to hyperventilate. He knows that preserving oxy is paramount, so he does his best to calm himself. The healthy swig he takes from his flask helps. 10.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He flips open the cell phone. The light of the display screen partially illuminates his face and some of the cof with a blueish hue. Paul again enters the overseas dialin code, this time dialing 411 information. The 411 OPERATOR answers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What city and state, please?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um...I don't know. The F.B.I., wherever they are. Paul reaches for his button-down shirt. Fishes for pens stashed in his lapel pocket, while keeping the phone pres to his ear with his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have a specific city you'd like to be connected to, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't care, any city. Just connect me to the F.B.I.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, I have F.B.I. field offices listed in Boston, New York, Philadelphia, New Haven, Los Angeles, Chicago, Denver -- Paul cannot bear to listen any further to this list that seemingly never ends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anywhere! Any city, just connect me, please!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, sir, but I'm not allowed to do that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine, um...Chicago. Okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please hold for your number. Paul is transferred to an AUTOMATED MESSAGE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The number you requested, 312-421- 6700... 11.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul writes the digits of the phone number on the top of coffin with his pen. But, after the first three numbers, pen stops working. He hurriedly reaches back into his shi pocket to remove the other pen, which is actually a click pencil. Click-click-click-click. He writes the last seven digits, followed by the word "FBI."

dialogues.speaker: AUTOMATED MESSAGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ...can be connected for an additional charge of twenty-five cents by pressing the number one. He presses the number one and is connected directly. After a few rings, SPECIAL AGENT HARRIS answers.

dialogues.speaker: SPECIAL AGENT HARRIS
dialogues.text: Chicago field office. Special Agent Harris.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello? Is this the F.B.I.?

dialogues.speaker: SPECIAL AGENT HARRIS
dialogues.text: Yes it is, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm calling from Iraq. I'm buried in the desert somewhere. I need you to help me --

dialogues.speaker: SPECIAL AGENT HARRIS
dialogues.text: Whoa, whoa, sir. Slow down. When were you in Iraq?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now. I'm there now. I'm a truck driver for CRT. I've been here for nine months.

dialogues.speaker: SPECIAL AGENT HARRIS
dialogues.text: May I have your name please, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul Conroy.

dialogues.speaker: SPECIAL AGENT HARRIS
dialogues.text: (saying it as he writes it

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul Conroy. (back on the phone) Okay, Paul, explain to me what's going on. 12.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul attempts to center himself so that he can accurately tell his story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright. Me and a convoy of other drivers were delivering kitchen parts to a community center. As we got closer, a bunch of kids started throwing rocks at our trucks. Then an IED went off up ahead and blew up one of the other trucks. These guys came out from behind the houses with guns and started shooting everybody right there on the street.

dialogues.speaker: SPECIAL AGENT HARRIS
dialogues.text: Were you shot at?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know! (after a breath, calmer) I don't know. I was way in the back of the convoy. I must have got hit in the head with one of the rocks and got knocked out. That's the last thing I remember. But now I just woke up, and I was tied up and buried in a coffin.

dialogues.speaker: SPECIAL AGENT HARRIS
dialogues.text: Who put you there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess whoever ambushed us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Special Agent Harris sounds slightly skeptical of Paul's claims.

dialogues.speaker: SPECIAL AGENT HARRIS
dialogues.text: A bunch of kids?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you're not listening. The kids threw the rocks at us, but then some Iraqi guys -- maybe insurgents, I don't fucking know -- popped out of nowhere and started shooting at us.

dialogues.speaker: SPECIAL AGENT HARRIS
dialogues.text: I thought you said they didn't shoot at you. 13.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They didn't, I don't know! But they shot them!

dialogues.speaker: SPECIAL AGENT HARRIS
dialogues.text: Sir, you're going to have to stop shouting if --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm shouting because you're not listening! I need you to help me! Please!!

dialogues.speaker: SPECIAL AGENT HARRIS
dialogues.text: Hmmm... Paul takes a moment to center himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you trace my call? GPS or something?

dialogues.speaker: SPECIAL AGENT HARRIS
dialogues.text: Why is it that they didn't shoot you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have no idea. They didn't, that's all I know.

dialogues.speaker: SPECIAL AGENT HARRIS
dialogues.text: What's your social security number, Paul?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why? Who cares? I'm buried in the middle of the fucking desert! Who cares what my social security number is?! I'm an American citizen. Just send someone to find me!

dialogues.speaker: SPECIAL AGENT HARRIS
dialogues.text: Do you know where you're ...lo...if...dy.. The cell phone starts breaking up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello? What? I can't hear you.

dialogues.speaker: SPECIAL AGENT HARRIS
dialogues.text: Bet...un...near... 14.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly, Special Agent Harris is not heard at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?! Hello?! Paul checks the phone's display, where he sees that the c has been lost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit!! Cell phone service temporarily goes down. Paul lights the Zippo to help him see the cell phone screen. He tries to make a call, but nothing happens. He shakes the phone, moves it around the coffin, all in desperate hope that he will get a signal. He soon does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at the number for the F.B.I. that he has written the wall, thinking about calling them back. He then check the battery life on his phone, which remains at two bars. Paul then decides to make a different call, this time to phone number he has committed to memory: his employer bac the U.S., Crestin, Roland and Thomas (CRT). He closes the lid of the Zippo, extinguishing the flame. After a few rings, a CRT OPERATOR answers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you for calling Crestin, Roland and Thomas. How may I direct your call?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somebody, I need to talk to someone right away. It's an emergency.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is this, please?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul Conroy. I'm a driver for you guys. I'm calling from Iraq. My convoy was attacked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, if this is a crisis situation you need to contact the Safety Number your were provided. 15.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, I know, but I don't have it. They took it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who took it, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Iraqis, I think. I don't remember, I blacked out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to put you through to Alan Davenport.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Davenport? Who's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Director of Personnel. Please hold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Personnel? No, I need to talk -- Paul is placed on hold. Synthesized soft rock plays in th background of the phone, maddening Paul further. Over the music, a CRT SPOKESMAN is heard, speaking a recorded testimonial during the on-hold message.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At CRT, we work with our clients to provide effective and sustainable solutions to the challenges they face in our fast-growing, global economy. As the premiere...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The message is interrupted by ALAN DAVENPORT's outgoing v message.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've reached Alan Davenport, personnel director at Crestin, Roland and Thomas. Please leave your name and number at the tone and I will return your call as soon as possible. The BEEP sounds. Paul is confused as to why he was patche through to someone in human resources, but leaves a messa nevertheless. 16.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Paul Conroy, I'm from Hastings, Michigan. I'm a driver for CRT, and my convoy was ambushed...by insurgents or terrorists. I don't know. I don't know who it was. I'm stuck in the ground, buried in a coffin and I need help. Please send help. I'm begging you. I think I'm in Baqubah in the Diyala Provence. Please send help right away. I can't breathe in here. I can't...please. I'm begging you. I don't know who else to call. I...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul notices that his phone has again lost signal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...fuck. Paul drops the phone to his side, the screen still emitti its glow. He explodes with a mixture of rage and fear. He screams a flails his feet and hands wildly, banging them against th walls of the coffin. His animalistic outburst causes the phone to close. The coffin returns to pitch black. After a long beat, Paul lights the Zippo, which remains wedged in the sand compacted against the small hole in th wall of the coffin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul takes a few moments to catch his breath. He looks ag at the cell phone. Remembers receiving a Text Message. The icon on the phone's display indicates that he does, i fact, have an unread Text Message waiting for him. Paul quickly scrolls through the phone's menu, which is a written in Arabic, until he reaches what appears to be th Text Message option. Opening it, he sees a series of ten numbers. Using his click-up pencil, he scribbles the numbers onto top of the coffin. Next to the number, he writes the word "HELP?" Noticing that his phone has again picked-up a signal, he dials the number. 17.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It rings once, but then the reception begins to falter. After only two rings, the call is ended. Paul's frustrati mounts. He is barely able to fight off another fit of hysterics. He dials the number again. It rings once. A second ring. In the middle of the third ring, someone answers -- but they do not say anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello? Hello? Is anyone there? Hello? After a beat, Paul hears breathing on the other end of th phone. He also hears a discordance of background sound; t din of a room filled with Arabic-speaking men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello? Who are you? Please, you have to help me. Still, Paul's words are only met with slow, measured brea

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is this? Hello? The person on the other end eventually speaks. An Iraqi m JABIR, talks forcefully and aggressively in broken Englis

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Breathe no breathe, American? Ah? Breathe no breathe?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? I don't know what you're saying. Who is this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: American can breathe no breathe?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I can't breathe. Please get me out of here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, please get me out. Help me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soldier. 18.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no I'm not a soldier. I'm a truck driver. That's it. I'm not a soldier. I'm a contractor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Contractor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, that's right. A contractor. Not a soldier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blackwater.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, not for Blackwater. I'm not a security contractor. Truck driver, I'm a truck driver. That's all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are American.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you are soldier. Despair falls upon Paul. It becomes clear that Jabir is responsible for all of this. As such, Paul crosses out th word "HELP?" Closes the lid of the Zippo, leaving only th cell phone display screen to illuminate his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm not. I'm here unarmed. But, you still shot at us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In head and in throat, so you tell no more lies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not lying! We were all drivers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drive what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trucks. The big trucks you see driving around with the supplies? That's us. That's me. We're not soldiers. 19.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five million money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five million money tonight by nine PM or you stay. Buried like dog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five million dollars? From who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My family doesn't have five million dollars. If they did, I wouldn't be here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From Embassy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, yes, the Embassy will pay you. If you let me go, they'll pay you the money. Silence on the other end of the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a long beat) Nine PM, five million money. Jabir hangs up the phone, forcing Paul to instantly come grips with the fact that he is being held hostage. He lays back in the coffin, shell-shocked. Physically spe the cell phone falls from his hands and onto the floor. T display screen casts a dim light throughout the coffin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Zippo lights. Paul holds it in his hand, using it to illuminate the inside of the coffin. He attempts to push into its now customary resting place, but the sand has loosened, making it difficult for the Zippo to stay in pl It almost falls to the floor. 20.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looking around, Paul sees there is a crack between two planks, located on the opposite wall of the coffin. He wedges the lit Zippo into the crack. With his hands now free, Paul haphazardly positions himse so that his back is facing the top of the coffin. His every move is arduous; the claustrophobic nature of t coffin bearing down on him. Paul positions his bent knees underneath his chest, with shins and feet pressed against the bottom of the coffin. Using the strength of his legs, he attempts to lift the t off the coffin with his back. Trickles of sand fall in from the side of the coffin, sprinkling against the wooden base.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He fails, only to immediately try again. And again. And again. Exhaustion sets in. Staring ahead, the phone sits in front of him. He notices that the battery life bars are still at one solid and one blinking. He grabs the cell phone, staring at it, trying to think o someone else to call. The battery life is limited. Every call has to count. He tries to remember some phone numbers, but has trouble recalling the information.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, what's her number?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He cannot remember the number he's thinking of. He notice that the flame of the Zippo flickers, indicating its use his much-needed oxygen. Paul closes the lid, extinguishin the flame. A second later, we see him, lit by the cell phone display screen. He dials the international code for the United States, followed by 411 information. A MALE 411 OPERATOR answers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What city and listing, please?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hastings, Michigan. I'm looking for Donna Mitchell. 21.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have two Donna Mitchells, sir. One on Federal Road and one on Ardmore Avenue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ardmore Avenue...I think. Yeah. Shit, I don't know. Just give me that one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ardmore Avenue?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Ardmore Avenue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please hold for your number. Paul is switched to an AUTOMATED MESSAGE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The number you requested, 269-948- 1998 can automatically be dialed for a charge of twenty-five cents by pressing the number one. Paul writes Donna's number and name on the top of the cof and then presses the number one. He is connected. Her phone rings and rings. Paul's frustration is evident.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on! Where the hell is everyone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The phone rings some more. Paul checks the battery life - still at one and a half bars. DONNA eventually answers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello? Hearing her voice, Paul hurriedly places the phone to his ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donna, it's Paul.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, how's it going? 22.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's Linda? She's not answering her phone. I need to talk to her, I've been taken hostage by... Donna interrupts. We realize, as does Paul, that her voic was actually coming from her answering machine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fooled you. I'm not really home. But if you leave a message, I'll get back to you as soon as I get in. Bye-bye. His hand falls to his forehead, defeated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donna, I need to talk to Linda. It's an absolute emergency. Have her call me. Use star sixty-nine and find out the number I'm calling from and have her call me... Donna picks up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donna.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need to talk to Linda. Where is she?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. I haven't talked to her all day. Call her cell phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you near a computer or something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh...yeah. Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turn it on. 23.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look up the number for the State Department for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was just heading out to the supermarket. I really don't have

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donna, please, please, please -- just get me the number.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is everything alright?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! Everything is not alright! So, please, just look up the number.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't fucking yell at me, Paul.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not yelling!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes you are. Just like you did last year at the cookout. I'm not going to tolerate --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just get me the fucking number!! Get me the number, get me the number!! Donna hangs up on him. Realizing this, Paul bangs his fis and claws at the top of the coffin, bloodying some of his fingers and knuckles in the process. He violently tosses and turns and screams at the top of h lungs, like an animal trapped in a cage. Tears spray from his eyes as spit shakes free from his mouth by the force his shudder. He eventually calms quite a bit. Sniffing away tears and taking notice of the damage he's done to his hands, Paul slows his breathing as best he can. 24.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lies there, motionless. The silence is almost comforting. Paul closes his eyes, regretfully accepting what appears will be his inescapabl fate. After a beat, he calls Donna back. Knowing it is Paul calling, she answers right away, attitude at the ready.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? It takes every ounce of Paul's being to keep himself from going off the deep end. He takes a beat to compose himsel and then finally offers a very delicate and deliberate response.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donna, I'm very sorry I yelled. But, I'm only going to ask you once more to get me this number. If you don't get me this number, I'm going to die.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't have time to explain. Please...the number.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold on. We hear Donna put down the phone. In the b.g., we hear th sound of keys being pressed on a computer keyboard. After a beat, she picks the phone back up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay...State Department. It's 202- 134-4750.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Paul writes the number on the top of the coffin, beneath man others. He writes the initials "S.D." next to it. 25.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell's going -- Paul hangs up on Donna mid-sentence. He dials the number State Department right away. A STATE DEPARTMENT REP answers after a few rings.

dialogues.speaker: STATE DEPARTMENT REP
dialogues.text: United States Department of State.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm an American citizen, working in Iraq. I've been taken hostage. I need to speak to someone right away.

dialogues.speaker: STATE DEPARTMENT REP
dialogues.text: Where are you calling from, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From Iraq. I'm a truck driver for CRT -- Crestin, Roland and Thomas. We were attacked and now I'm being held for ransom.

dialogues.speaker: STATE DEPARTMENT REP
dialogues.text: Are the kidnappers with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I'm buried somewhere.

dialogues.speaker: STATE DEPARTMENT REP
dialogues.text: You're buried?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, in a coffin, a wooden box. It's an old coffin, I think.

dialogues.speaker: STATE DEPARTMENT REP
dialogues.text: Did you try contacting the military out there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't have the number.

dialogues.speaker: STATE DEPARTMENT REP
dialogues.text: What number?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was given a number to call, a safety number. But the people took it. 26.

dialogues.speaker: STATE DEPARTMENT REP
dialogues.text: The people holding you hostage?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know...hold on. Let me connect you...hold on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Wait... Paul is placed on hold. As he waits, his eyes wander arou the coffin. He looks at the numbers he has written.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After a moment, REBECCA BROWNING, a State Department official, picks up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rebecca Browning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, hello. I was just informed of your situation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, my situation. I'm running out of time and you people keep putting me on hold. What the hell is wrong with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be sorry. Just help me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just have a few questions for you, Mister Conroy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've got to be kidding me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's important that I get this information. It will make a rescue

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait, wait, wait...how did you know my name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never gave you my name. I don't think I gave it to the other guy, either. Rebecca is silent on the other end of the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell is going on right now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a beat) We received a call from a representative at CRT. You left him a message?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He contacted us right away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, since you know what the hell is going on, what have you done to get me out of here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's little we can do from Washington.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, that's it? I'm just supposed to rot in here because there's little you can do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need to know where you were when your convoy was ambushed. 28.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the Diyala Provence. In Baqubah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. And has contact been made with the kidnappers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. The guy told me that he wants five million dollars by nine o'clock tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or else...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or else he'll bring me to Sea World. What do you think, lady? Even faced with Paul's sarcasm, Rebecca remains stolid. Professional.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll do everything we can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you'll pay them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. That we can't do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait...what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the policy of the United States government to not negotiate with terrorists.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To hell with that! It's easy for you to worry about policy, you're sitting in an air conditioned office somewhere, probably finishing up your sandwich from lunch. You're not the one stuck in a coffin, buried in the God damn desert!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand your frustration -- 29.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frustration? Lady, I'm going to fucking die in here. Understand that! Rebecca is silent on the other end of the phone. Paul wonders if she is still there. The idea of being alone ag scares him terribly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello? Worried, Paul lights the Zippo. The reflection of the fla dances on his frightened eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Momentary relief. After a beat:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, then say something. Tell me how you're going to get me out of here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the number on the phone you're calling from?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Did it come up on your end?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. It's listed as unavailable. Do this -- take down this number.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul takes out his pen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go ahead.
Paul writes the number onto the top of the coffin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dan Brenner. He's the commander of the Hostage Working Group over in Iraq. 30.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul writes "D. BRENNER" next to Dan's phone number.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hostage Working Group?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We formed it in 2004 to deal with situations such as yours. Paul shakes his head in disgust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Situations. I love how you keep calling it that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you write down the number?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. Hold on, I'll connect you with him now. He should be expecting you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about the news? I'm going to call them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Do not, I repeat, do not contact the news.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It will only complicate things further and threaten your chances of rescue. Paul doesn't buy it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's bullshit. You're just covering your ass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm covering yours. Everyone who needs to know about this does. 31.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't go looking for something if you don't know it's missing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's why you need to contact Dan Brenner right away. Paul still contemplates contacting the news, but soon acquiesces to Rebecca's pleas for him not to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm transferring you now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rebecca's gone. Paul waits. Several beeps sound as he's being transferred. Paul hears a faint sound coming from behind him, outside coffin. While the beeps continue to sound, he lights the Zippo, circumspectly looking behind him. He doesn't see anything. With the Zippo still lit, Paul takes a deep, centering breath, followed by another. A few more long beeps pass before a ring is heard. After rings, DAN BRENNER answers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brenner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dan Brenner?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dan is quick to figure out who it is that must be calling him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this Paul Conroy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, yes it's me. It's Paul.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul, I was informed of what's going on. I want you to know that we're already working on trying to get you out of there. 32.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul is relieved. His first glint of hope has appeared. Tears of joy instantly escape his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, thank you, God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was told that we have until 9pm. Is that right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what he said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright. That doesn't give us a whole lot of time. And just so I have this right, the kidnappers buried you in the ground?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, in an old, wooden coffin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. My guess is that since you're able to get a cell signal, you're no more than a few feet underground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Maybe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about battery life? How much does the phone have left? Paul looks at the display to find out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Less than half.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. You have to conserve that battery. Our best bet of finding you is by tracking your cell signal. Is the ringer set on a sound or vibrate?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vibrate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Press and hold down the asterisk key to change it to a ring tone. It will use less power. 33.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about my Zippo?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have a lighter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Use it to look around for markings, a logo -- whatever you can find.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Won't it use up oxygen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not much. Don't worry about that now. Try to find --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's really dark in here without it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand, Paul. Try to find anything in there that might indicate where that coffin was made.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You guys have to hurry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're working as fast as we can, Paul.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know if there were any other survivors?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From your convoy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's still unclear at this point.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just wanted to do right by my family. That's all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't know it was going to be like this over here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think any of us did. While on the phone with Brenner, Paul gets another call coming in. He checks the display and reads the number. Matching it against a number he wrote on the top of the coffin, he sees that is Jabir calling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's him. He's calling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The kidnapper?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. What do I do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know his number?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give it to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about the call?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me the number first. The phone has rung several times. Paul fears that Jabir m hang up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's going to hang up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take the call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take the call. Now. Paul complies with Dan's demand and switches to the other line. 35.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two hour, six minute. Paul looks at his watch. Indeed, he has but two hours and six minutes until the time reaches 9pm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have to give me more time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You talk to embassy? They give money?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. No. I talked to...someone. Government. They said that they won't pay the money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No pay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. They said that they don't negotiate with terrorists.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terrorists? I am terrorist?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. You are terrorist, you son of a bitch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are terrified, so I am terrorist?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did I ever do to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ever do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. I'm here because it's a job, to make money. That's it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have job until you come. Now, my family have nothing. 36.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not my fault! Jabir retorts with a spirited conviction similar to Paul'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nine, one, one was not my fault, but still you are here! Saddam was not my fault, but still you are here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you, I'm only here to work. To help rebuild.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rebuild what you destroyed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul cannot handle his stress any longer. He begins to crumble under the pressure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop! Just please, stop! I'm just a guy. I'm just a truck driver. Okay? I'm nobody that makes decisions about anything. I just want to go home. Silence from the other end of the phone for an extended period of time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You make video, ransom video. This surprisingly comes as good news to Paul.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Please. Get me out of here and I'll make the video.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. You make video now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What...? How?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You use video on phone. Paul's hopes are dashed. His sanguine head falls back ont the coffin floor. 37.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Near foot. You read note near foot in box. Paul shines the flame of his Zippo lighter toward his fee He doesn't see anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where? I don't see --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Near foot. Read note inside box. Paul repositions his legs as best he can. He can vaguely the corner of a small metal box, partially sticking out o broken plank on the bottom of the coffin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The video...if I make it, will you let me go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only if we get money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody's going to pay five million dollars for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We take less. One million money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If they pay it, will you let me go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a beat) One million money. Jabir hangs up, ending the call. Paul sits motionless for a moment, soaking in all that Ja has just told him. He again looks down toward his feet. He can see the protruding corner of the metal box, but it's positioned i such a way that it will clearly not be easy for him to re it. Paul then tries to clasp the box with his feet, but after several unsuccessful attempts, he realizes that a new strategy is necessary. 38.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He makes efforts to reposition himself in the coffin, so his head and feet will ultimately switch places. He struggles, inch by troubled inch, to make this maneuver. Sweat pours down the side of his face. The extremely tigh quarters of the coffin make the repositioning nearly impossible. After expending a great deal of energy doing so, Paul eventually completes the turn of his body. He examines th small, rusted metal box. On it is a cartoon picture of a small Arab boy and girl playing with a red rubber ball. Skeptical at first, Paul carefully examines the box and shakes it gently. Items are heard rummaging inside. He carefully opens it. A fluorescent green light shines f inside. Paul looks inside and finds a lit, green glow stick, fluorescing brightly and now illuminating much of the cof He closes the lid of the Zippo. Removes the stick. Looking into the small box again, he finds several other items: a small, disused flashlight; a second, unlit glow stick; a jackknife; and lastly, a folded piece of paper. He slowly unfolds the piece of paper. We see that his ran message is written in an unintelligible mix of English an Arabic. Paul shakes his head and lets out a sigh of disgust. He crumbles up the paper into a ball and listlessly drops it his side. He covers his face with his hands, his labored breaths echoing in his palms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Under the low-light of the green glow stick, Paul picks u the phone and dials his home. Per usual, he gets the answering machine. His son, Shane, heard on outgoing message.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks for calling the Conroy's. We're not home right now. Please leave a message at the beep. Thanks. Paul's eyes well up with tears. He smiles at the sound of his son's voice. The Beep is heard. Paul hangs up without leaving a message. He looks at the time. It's 7:02pm. Battery life is holdin steady at one and a half bars. He remembers something. 39.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit. Paul presses and holds down the shortcut button on the ph that changes the ringer from vibrate to an audible tone. The glow stick begins to slowly fade. Paul dials Dan Brenner. After a few rings, Dan answers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's his number...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul presses the green key, bringing up the last numbers dialed and received.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold on. Alright, go ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's 07902-24-921. Dan says something to someone who is in the room with him and then returns his attention to Paul.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is huge. Unless they're using a cloned line, we should be able to find where this is coming from in minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about me? Can you track my cell signal?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're having a lot of trouble with yours. Seems to be an EDS line, probably through one of the Egyptian carriers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does that mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That...it's not going to be easy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wants me to make a ransom video. 40.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Hold off for as long as you can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If it's going to get me out of here, I'm making it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The last thing we want is for this to end up all over Al Jazeera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We? Paul becomes angry, again sensing that more emphasis is b placed on containing the situation than rescuing him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This can't turn into an international incident.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all you people care about! But what about me? Don't you care about me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We do. That's why we're --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No you don't! You people don't care about any of us. I've had eight friends killed out here, six of them today. We don't have any guns, any armor. Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not soldiers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell that to the people who put me in this box! Tell that to the people who shot my friends!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're doing the best we can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you're not. All you people understand are your secret plans and your back room politics.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I were some diplomat or something, maybe even a hostage working group leader -- or whatever your fancy title is, I'd be out of here by now. Wouldn't I? But I'm not, so I'm just supposed to keep my mouth shut and die.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need you to stay focused, Paul.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck you. Dan's heard enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul, listen to me: finding you is our primary concern. Bottom line. And we're searching just as hard as we would be for a four-star general, so don't literally waste your breath suggesting otherwise. Paul does not respond at first. Dan's retort clearly has effect on him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are they? The people who put me here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're just that -- people. No different from you and me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm no terrorist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neither are they.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you know that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you were homeless, starving...actually, I take that back. If your family was homeless and starving, what would you do for them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wouldn't kill someone. 42.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can you be sure?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What difference does it make?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're criminals, desperate ones at that. They don't care about anything other than getting the money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So pay them, then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trust me, if it was an option, I would do that in a heartbeat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many others have there been?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Since I got here? Hundreds. Journalists, contractors, soldiers...hundreds have been taken. It's one of the only functioning businesses out here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many have you rescued? Dan is reluctant to answer the question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not many.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me their names.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any of them. Make me know they really do matter to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark White. 43.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who was Mark White?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A kid from New Hampshire. Twenty- six years old. Med student. Came over here to help out local doctors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened to him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Insurgents grabbed him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About three weeks ago. Paul writes "MARK WHITE" on the top of the coffin, below list of phone numbers. He circles the name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You remember his name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I remember all their names.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (afraid to ask) Did he...? Is he...? The glow stick begins to fade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Yeah, Paul, he's alive. Hearing this affords Paul some semblance of relief. Paul shakes the glow stick, returning it to its full strength.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Home. Probably happy to be back at school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to get out of here. 44.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We found him; we'll find you, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We already have a solid lead on the number you gave us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A unit's on it's way over there now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This news calms Paul's nerves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's...that's good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What should I do in the meantime?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know it's hard, but try to relax. The more worked up you are, the more air you're going to use.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't help it. I'm always anxious. I take pills for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have them with you? Paul checks his pants pockets. He removes a small, orange pill bottle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take them. You need to preserve your oxygen level any way you can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. 45.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is your Zippo still lit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel nauseous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have to calm down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm trying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you need to save that battery. We're expecting some intel in about ten minutes. Call me back then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just hang in there, Paul. The glow stick begins to slowly fade. Paul shakes it, causing it to brighten only momentarily before dimming ag

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. I'm trying. Dan ends the call. Paul lets out a deep breath, finding i difficult to lay claim to its replacement. He looks at his watch. It's now 7:18pm. The ticking sound of the second hand turning is inordinately loud, due to t extreme silence of the coffin. Just then, the cell phone rings. Checking the number on t display, Paul sees that it is Jabir. Paul answers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you make video? 46.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Jabir yells something in Arabic to the other Iraqi men we hear in the background. Collectively, they do not sound pleased. Slightly panicke in fact, though it is difficult to tell for sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You make video!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me out and I'll make it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! You make video now. In box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't. I can't read the paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Make video now!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't. I don't know what you want me to say. I can't read the paper. Jabir is heard speaking with the men we hear arguing in t background. Although they speak in Arabic, it is clear fr their tone that they are becoming worried and increasingl hostile. Jabir returns his attention back to Paul.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You make video now. Jabir ends the call. Paul closes the phone to help conser battery life. He then reopens the phone and scrolls through the menu options. Everything is written in Arabic. He eventually comes across an icon with a movie camera -- the video function. He turns it on. Looks at himself though the viewfinder. After a beat, he closes the phone, clearly frustrated and growing more panicked. His breaths grow heavy and rapid, utilizing a great deal of oxygen. 47.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm never getting out of here. Paul begins to freak out, restlessly squirming inside the coffin and pressing against the sides and top. The glow stick fades out almost completely, offering very little light. Paul shakes it, but with no change to its brightness. Moments later, it dies. Paul tries the flashlight. Click-click. Click-click. Nothing. He bangs it a few times with his hand. The white light tu on, but quickly turns back off. He twists the top, which causes the flashlight to switch bulbs. A red beam emits momentarily. Paul twists the top again and gives the flashlight a few good whacks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It turns on. White light shines dimly on his face. He takes a breath. In efforts to calm himself, he once again removes the ora pill bottle from his pocket. He pours two into his hand. then removes his small, metal alcohol flask from his back pocket and takes a large swig, swallowing the two pills i the process. Still, Paul's heavy, labored breathing continues. He drop four additional pills into his and swallows them with yet another generous pull from the flask. He sits and waits. Nothing is happening, except that his extremely limited time keeps passing. After a moment, Paul picks up the cell phone. He holds it front of him, hesitant to make a call. After some consideration, he dials. After a few rings, a NURSING HOME NURSE answers.

dialogues.speaker: NURSING HOME NURSE
dialogues.text: Mountain View Nursing Home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was hoping I could speak with Maryanne Conroy, please.

dialogues.speaker: NURSING HOME NURSE
dialogues.text: Um...okay. Ah...let me bring the cordless phone to her room. Hold on a moment, please. We hear the Nurse walk down the tiled corridor floor. She soon reaches Paul's mother's room. 48.

dialogues.speaker: NURSING HOME NURSE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Misses Conroy, you have a telephone call, dear. Here, you can use this phone. Paul's mother, MARYANNE, answers. Her voice is pleasant b confused. It's clear that she suffers from advanced stage of Alzheimer's Disease.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom...it's Paul.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Paul, Mom. Your son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My son?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay, Mom. How are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's your son, Mom. It's Paulie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paulie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Remember? We lived over on Colfax Street, in the duplex. Remember?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paulie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right, Mom. 49.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this Paulie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is, Mom. It's Paulie. How's everything at the home?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very nice. Your father and I have been playing gin rummy every night. It's almost too much for Paul to take. He cries silent te over a heartbroken smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah...I don't think Pop's there with you, Mom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How are you doing, sweetie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not very good. This...uh, this may be the last time I talk to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's nice, honey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you get the flowers I sent a few months ago?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flowers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I sent...never mind. Listen, I...I'm going to go now. I just wanted to talk to you, you know, just to say bye. I love you, Mom. Maryanne doesn't respond.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you hear me? Mom? I told you...do you want to tell me you

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, dear. Your father and I have been playing gin rummy every night. 50.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a beat) Okay, Mom. Tell Pop I said hi. Paul ends the call and instantly begins crying his heart He lays there, sobbing relentlessly. After a long beat, the cell phone rings. Decidedly differ than his past reactions to an incoming call, Paul seems hopelessly disinterested. The ring is maddening. He mindlessly presses the shortcut button, resetting the to vibrate mode. He eventually picks up the phone, but there is not anyone the other end. It's then that he sees that it was not a c that came in, but instead was a picture message. Pressing what appears to be the Accept button, the incomi picture begins to download. Several seconds later, the picture downloads and an image appears on the display of Paul's cell phone. It's of a wo -- bound and gagged, a gun pressed against the side of he head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no. No, no, no! Paul frantically dials the number to reach Jabir. As soon the phone connects, Paul begins his desperate plea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Video make?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let her go. Please. Please don't hurt her. The Woman is heard in the background of Jabir's phone, cr muffled words through her muzzled mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We shoot her if you no make video.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! No, please no shoot. No shoot her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You get money. American million. 51.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will, I promise. Just don't shoot her. She's a mother, she's got two kids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two kids?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. She has two kids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have five. Now only one. You make video. Now!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No wait!! I give three seconds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't read the paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Wait!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what you want me to say!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay! Okay, I'll make the video. Just, please, don't shoot. Jabir does not fire his gun. Paul attempts to catch his breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need to hang up to make the video. Okay? Is that okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have three minute to send video. 52.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jabir hangs up, ending the call. Paul reaches for the balled-up piece of paper that has th ransom script written on it. It takes some trouble for hi to grab it, but he is soon able to. Placing the flashlight next to the paper, Paul is again reminded of the incoherent nature of the script.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (re: the script) Fuck... He drops the paper to his side and opens the phone, setti it to the video record function. He places the flashlight close to his face so as to make his image more visible on small, phone display screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He presses the record button.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (speaking at the phone) My name is Paul Conroy. I'm an American citizen from Hastings, Michigan. I'm a civilian truck driver for Crestin, Roland and Thomas. I've been taken hostage somewhere in Iraq...and I need one million dollars by nine o'clock tonight, Baghdad time, or else I'll be left to die in this coffin I'm buried in. I've been told that if... The flashlight goes out. Paul continues speaking in the darkness. After a few quick smacks, the flashlight turns back on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...the money is paid, I will be let go. If it's not, I will die in here. These threats are real and will be followed through on. Trying to think of more to say, Paul soon opts for not sa anything further. He saves the message and then sends it Jabir. We see that the screen displays an icon confirming the vi has been sent. Paul places the phone on his chest. Still rubbing his temples, his eyes begin to flutter a bit. He tries to control his breathing and remain calm. 53.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He opens the phone and displays the photo of the Woman. H stares admiringly at her, hoping dearly that she will not harmed. The effects of the anxiety pills finally taking effect, h eyes soon close and he drifts off to sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darkness once again. We hear the sound of Paul slowly awaking, followed the sight of Zippo sparks. It doesn't catch. The second glow stick is snapped, illuminating the coffin with a fluorescent green hue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul starts to move, but suddenly freezes. His eyes widen His pupils dilate. Something is clearly very wrong, thoug we cannot see what. His eyes slowly shift downward, as if watching something down his body. Beads of sweat form across his brow. His measured breaths are held for as long as they can be. Moving excruciatingly slow, Paul lowers the glow stick to what he is looking at. A shape moves across his stomach, underneath his T-shirt. Paul's eyes are fixed on whatever it may be. He cautiousl slowly, moves the glow stick even closer. The shape disappears just as the light of the glow stick shines on whatever it may be. Still, Paul does not dare m any sudden move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul's pant leg moves slightly, starting at the top, slow undulating toward his cuff. Paul leans the glow stick in further. And further. Carefully. Moving a millimeter at a time. He shifts the position of his head slightly, charily, to see next to hi feet. He leans in even closer with the glow stick. But then -- -- his wary movement comes to immediate stop. It's a snake. A two-foot, saw-scaled viper. It has positioned itself in the corner of the coffin, inches fro Paul's feet. 54.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His terror evident, Paul very slowly pulls his feet back toward his upper body, away from the snake. The confined space offers little room for safety. The snake turns its muscled neck to face Paul. Their eyes meet for the first time. The snake hisses, poised to stri at any moment. Paul raises his foot. Steels himself. Prepares to preempt the snake with a solid stomp. A more sensible plan soon prevails. After lowering his fo Paul cautiously removes the flask from his pocket. Slowly unscrews the top. Splashes a small amount of alcohol on t floor, close to the snake. The snake recoils slightly, but then menacingly twists it into a new posture, ready to attack. Paul lowers the Zipp to the small puddle of alcohol. After a few sparks --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- it lights. A flash-fire. The snake flails and hisses wildly at the other side of a small fire wall. The flame soon goes out. Paul moves fast. Throws more alcohol, this time some of it lands on the snake itself. places the already lit Zippo against the puddle of alcoho near the snake. Another flash-fire, this time burning the snake. It hisse loudly. Threateningly. It swings back and forth, challenging the small wall of fire. The fire soon extinguishes. The snake burrows into the ho from where it likely entered the coffin, disappearing int with haste. Paul hurriedly stuffs the hole with his discarded button- shirt. He then pours a small amount of alcohol over the shirt and temporarily puts the flask on the ground, but d not screw the cap on securely. He then wedges the lit Zip between a small space between two wooden planks. With the snake situation handled, Paul finally lets out a sigh of relief. Rubs his eyes. Tries to regain his faculties. Looks over the list of phone numbers written above him. Suddenly, the cell phone vibrates. Paul frenziedly search for it, but he cannot find it. He then notices it has fal into the small hole near his feet, out of his reach. He makes several attempts to grab the phone with his feet but he is unable to do so. It continues to ring. His next efforts involve repositioning himself in the cof so that he completely turns to face the opposite end. 55.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Struggling through each move, Paul painstakingly begins t turn himself. While turning, however, he inadvertently ki the Zippo from the side of the coffin -- landing it on th floor, up against the glow stick -- and knocks over the flask. We see that the flame of the Zippo slowly melts the plast glow stick, causing it to dim slightly. Worst still, and completely unbeknownst to Paul, a stream alcohol slowly makes its way from the flask and toward th flame of the lighter, threatening to set the coffin ablaz Inch by inch, the flammable spirit gets closer. Still in the midst of his repositioning, Paul looks back sees the alcohol nearing the flame. In a panic, he attemp to reach and grab the Zippo. But, he finds himself stuck the middle of the coffin. He can't budge either way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, no!! Desperately straining every muscle in his body, he extend his arm backward toward the Zippo, hoping to move it away from the spilled alcohol. He still can't reach it, yet he tries with all his might. The phone stops ringing. He has missed the call. He tries blowing at the flame, but his head is too far aw and his breath is not strong enough to do much more than cause it to flicker. With the alcohol now mere inches away from the flame, Pau reaches for his shoe. His odd positioning makes reaching foot almost impossible. He struggles to undo the laces an remove it from his foot. With his face beet red from the force of his strain, Paul finally removes his shoe. The mere inch of leg room this creates allows him to slide his leg out from under him.
