The trail of alcohol is just about to come into contact w the flame -- -- but Paul deftly maneuvers his body just in time to awkwardly kick the Zippo out of the way and close the lid Paul breaths an enormous sigh of relief as he sits in the light of the damaged glow stick. He notices another hole the coffin. As a precaution, he stuffs it with the cloth that had previously been used to gag him. 56.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just as he is about to grab the phone, he hears what appe to be the faint sound of a Muslim call to prayer being announced over the citywide PA system. The sound barely makes its way through the hundreds of pounds of sand that envelop the coffin. A sign of hope, as well as a point of reference for his location -- albeit a very vague one. He listens further as the call to prayer continues. The light of the glow stick dims further. Paul then opens his phone. Sees that he missed Jabir's ca He starts to call Jabir back, but stops. He instead navigates through the various display menus. He soon reac what appears to be the Tools Menu, though it's difficult tell because everything is written in Arabic. He becomes frustrated as he fails to find what he is looking for. On the verge of mental surrender, he sees something that gives him pause. A smile crosses his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (re: the phone screen) There you are. We see, on the display of the phone, that Paul has found listing of languages. He scrolls past many -- "FRANCAIS, DETSCHE, ESPANOL" -- stopping at "ENGLISH." Presses the button, instantly making all the text on the screen reada He quickly navigates to the Tools menu. Scrolls down. Locates the number of the cell phone he is using. He scribbles the number onto the top of the coffin. Then second pass, making it bolder than the others. Paul then dials his wife's cell phone. After only a few rings, he is met by her voice mail.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Hi, this is Linda. Please leave a message. Thanks and have a great day. The beep sounds, and Paul frantically proceeds right into message.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Linda, here's the number for the phone. I just found it out. It's 07902-42-884. You have to use the international calling code first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please call me as soon as you get this. I love you...I love you. Call me right away. Please. Paul hangs up. He looks at the battery life left on the phone. One bar. He then checks his watch. It's 8:19pm. Both are not good signs, and he knows it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh shit. He begins to panic. Grabbing the pocket knife that was le inside the metal box, he slides the blade in the space between the sides of the coffin and the top. Paul grabs the glow stick. But, because it was partially melted to the floor, the stick snaps in two. Liquid oozes out of the small portion of the stick that remains stuck floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Son of a... Paul grabs the flashlight. Turns it on. It works for a second, but then goes out. Shaking it only produces intermittent beams of light. He turns the top, switching to the red bulb. It works. Th coffin fills with a reddish hue, but then it, too, goes o Growing incensed, Paul switches back to the white bulb. I works. He returns his attention to the coffin. His efforts to us the knife as a fulcrum are futile. Still, he tries. Bendi the blade well past its design, it nearly breaks off its handle. The flashlight turns off. After a good shaking, it turns back on, emitting white light. With oxygen levels extremely diminished, efforts of this are all too much for Paul to take. He has to stop and try catch his breath. As he endeavors to get his wind back, the cell phone ring Not a call this time, but instead a video message. It has been sent by Jabir. Paul's trepidation is evident. He fears what the incoming video may show. 58.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After a beat, he presses the Accept button and the video downloads. Within seconds, the video plays on his phone display screen. We see, in the video, the American Woman that previously appeared in a picture message that was se to Paul. She is still bound at her wrists, but her gag ha been lowered. She sits on her knees. Standing behind her are three men, all with their faces shielded by Arab headdresses. They e hold AK-47 assault weapons. Paul watches in horror as the terrified woman speaks, thr her tears, into the camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My name is Pamela Gorham. I'm a food service worker at F.O.B. Anaconda, employed by Crestin, Roland and Thomas. My captors' requests for ransom have gone unanswered, and -- The Woman, Pamela, looks off-screen to her right. Someone fast approaching her. She cowers, protectively holding he bound hands in front of her face as she screams.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the person) No...wait!! Please -- no!! Another Iraqi man steps into the camera's line of site, a handgun already brandished. Without as much as a moment's hesitation, he fires two ro directly into Pamela's head, killing her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The video message ends immediately thereafter. Paul is in complete shock. He screams aloud, slamming his closed fist against the bo of the coffin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! No, no, no!!! Still in the throes of emotional torment, Paul vomits on himself. He doubles over, only to vomit once again. His body, taxed almost to the point of complete physical breakdown, gradually slows and levels itself. With his vo smeared face pressed cheek-down onto the bottom of the coffin, Paul stares into nothingness. 59.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After a beat, his eye catches a glimmer of light -- the b of the knife, reflecting off the beam of the flashlight. Paul reaches for the knife. Lying on his back, still suffering enormous mental strain, he places the cutting e of the blade against his neck. His jugular vein. His hand shakes, his lips tremble. The hand that holds the blade tightens its grip on the handle. It, too, shakes. Paul closes his eyes. A small amount of blood begins to drip from the side of h neck, where the blade of the knife rests, ready to open h vein.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After a great deal of consideration, Paul throws the knif the foot of the coffin. He can't do it. The flashlight falls from Paul's chest. It turns off upon landing on the floor of the coffin. Paul sits in darkness. His breaths echo off the coffin walls. After a beat, he turns on the flashlight. It turns off af less than two seconds. This time, however, he does not sh it, nor does he hit it. A moment later, we hear a click, followed by the sight of red light beam emitting from the flashlight. It holds steady.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul shines it onto the names and phone numbers written o the top of the coffin. He stops at "MARK WHITE." After a beat, he lowers the flashlight to his side. He picks up the phone and dials Brenner. After one ring, Brenner answers. He's clearly not pleased. Paul, however, is surprisingly calm. Detached. Almost disturbingly so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why the hell did you make that video?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all a bunch of lies. 60.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is? What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All of what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody gives a shit about any of us. We're nothing to you people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're going to find you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By looking the other way?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't start breaking on me now, Paul. You have to stay strong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You let her die.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a beat) No I didn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They shot her...and you didn't do anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We didn't even know she had been taken hostage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sent three videos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what they told her to say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you know? 61.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That your ransom video already has 47,000 hits on YouTube. And all the major networks are playing it, including Al Jazeera. So, now your captors have no choice but to follow through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I found out the number to this phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I found a way to change the display language. I figured that out, and you didn't. Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I didn't. Just like you and every other person on this planet, there are some things I know and some things I don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then how are you ever going to find me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Their signal was cloned, like we figured. But, we're close. Real close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about mine?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're working on that, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm near a Mosque. I could hear the call to prayer over the P.A.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. That means that we're in the right area.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're nearby? 62.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I spoke with soldiers from the third ID who were escorting your convoy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're alive? After a beat:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not all of them. Both Bradley tanks were hit with IEDs. The rest got caught in small arms fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell happened out there, Paul?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul doesn't answer at first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul. After a beat:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We had just left Anaconda, everything seemed okay. We knew that a bunch of our CB radios had been stolen and that the Iraqis were listening in, so we made sure to switch from our usual channels. Pam was riding with Jeff Breer, the convoy commander. She wanted to ride with me like she usually did when she hitched a ride from base, but it seemed safer for her to be with the C.C. As we headed down the road, all these kids came running into the street. Dozens of them. It almost seemed like they were expecting us, except we got there faster than they thought we would. So they run on up in front of me, and I slam on my brakes. The rest of the drivers were already further up ahead, so they kept going. Next thing I know, one of the lead trucks got hit by an IED. I hear Tommy Wilkes on the radio saying, Sandman's hit, Sandman's hit. He's...he's everywhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's when the Iraqis came out of their mud huts from the side of the road and started shooting everybody. I couldn't believe what was happening. It seemed like slow- motion, like I was watching it on TV. People -- my friends -- were getting killed, and all I could do is watch. I didn't even notice that the kids were throwing bricks and rocks at me until one split my windshield. Sort of snapped me out of my trance. But then, I guess I got hit in the head with a rock, `cause I blacked out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you happen to remem...mo... nea... The cell phone service begins to cut out. Suddenly, the coffin begins to vibrate slightly, dropping sand granules through the crack and onto the wood bottom, followed by t faint sound of an explosion. Within seconds, the explosions grow louder and more proximate. The vibration becomes so intense that it violently shakes Paul around the coffin. The sound of jet plane engines are heard coming from abov flying by as the massive explosions continue. Sand seeps in through the crack between the top and sides the coffin as it shakes. Paul does his best to brace himself, but the bombardment is far too powerful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A large crack forms in the wooden cover to the coffin, spanning almost its entire length. Sand immediately pours through the concave shaped crack, seeping in onto Paul li an hourglass. Fearing that the top of the coffin may collapse under the immense pressure from the sand above, Paul positions hims underneath it and presses with all his might. He grunts a screams loudly, using what little strength he has left to keep the top from caving. The shaking soon stops, though the steady flow of sand continues. 64.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In efforts to prevent the sand from filling the coffin an faster, Paul removes the button-down shirt from the hole stuffs into the area where it enters with the greatest volume. He removes the balled-up cloth from the other hol and does the same with it. Both offer very little help. The flashlight falls to the floor. The red light beam tur off. Darkness. The sound of sand steadily pouring down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no...no... Paul clicks the flashlight to a different setting. White light shines, but then goes out. He shakes the flashlight and it stays on, shining its normal white beam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He assesses his situation, noticing that the coffin is already filled with a small layer of sand; a situation th is only going to get worse with time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This can't be happening. We see that Dan Brenner is no longer on the phone, and th the display menu shows an icon of a phone with a line thr it -- No Service Available. Once he feels it is secure enough, Paul slowly moves his away from the crack. Although slightly caved, it does not show any more signs of possible collapse. Sweat drenches his face. His eyes affixed, in utter disbelief, on the sand as it spills into the coffin, fill in around him inch-by-inch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He grabs the cell phone, only to see that he does not hav signal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Come on. Please work. He shakes the cell phone and moves it all around the coff hoping that it may somehow help. His efforts are futile. The flashlight goes dead. He hits it, shakes it. It turns back on. The brightness is diminished. Still the sand continues to fall, drowning him deeper and deeper in a pool of granules. Then, very surprisingly, the cell phone rings. Paul answe right away. 65.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello? Hello? Who's there? Alan Davenport answers calmly from the other end.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this Paul Conroy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Yes, this is Paul. Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul, my name's Alan Davenport, I'm the personnel director here at Crestin, Roland and Thomas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I left you a message.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You did. I also heard from Rebecca Browning over at the State Department. Are you able to speak on the status of your situation?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's worse. There was an explosion or something. The coffin's breaking, there's sand pouring in from everywhere. I only have a half an hour before --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, okay. Slow down. You should try to stay calm. Tell me something, Paul, who have you spoken to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hostage takers, Dan Brenner from the hostage working group --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, Paul. I'm with you. How about the media. I know your ransom video leaked, but have you spoken directly to anyone about what's going on? The flashlight goes out. Paul hits it a few times and it turns back on. 66.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's good. It needs to stay that way. It's important that we keep this situation as contained as possible. Paul finds Alan's obvious concern with doing damage contr to be infuriating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About three inches to my right, there's a wall. Three inches to my left, there's another wall. And about four inches above my head, there's a roof that's about to collapse and drown me in sand. I think this situation is pretty contained.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you're upset --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Help me! Help me! What are you going to do to help me?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you're upset. And, from what I've been told, steps are being taken to get you out of there. So, hopefully it won't be much longer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, thank God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to switch on a recorder right now. Just a second... Paul's visage expresses his confusion. A click is heard in the b.g. of Alan's phone, followed by low, steady hum. Alan's speech becomes very laconic. His questions are clearly being read from a Human Resources handbook of som kind. 67.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN DAVENPORT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This is Alan Davenport, Personnel Director for Crestin, Roland and Thomas, Incorporated. The date is October 23, 2006. I am speaking with Paul Conroy. Mister Conroy, are you aware that I'm recording this conversation?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please answer the question. The flashlight goes out again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit. Paul hits it, but it does not catch. He sits in darkness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mister Conroy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Yes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And do I have your permission to do so?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you need my permission? What is all this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need you to answer yes or no, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Alright? Yes! Paul hits the flashlight. It turns back on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. Now, Mister Conroy, when were you hired by CRT?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About nine months ago. Around January of 2005. Why are you wasting time with this? 68.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have your official date of hire as January 4th, 2005. Is that correct?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who cares? This is fucking crazy --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: January 4th, 2005. Is that correct?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And during your initial training, before being sent to Iraq, were you made aware of the dangers inherent to the position for which you were hired.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean when I came down there to Dallas and you guys said that all of the trucks would be armored and have bulletproof glass? The flashlight dims. Paul angrily shakes it, returning it full strength.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean when you told us that things were safer than ever over here? Is that when I was made aware?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need you to answer yes or no, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. The flashlight begins to slowly dim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: During that time, did you also receive and sign an employment contract with CRT, which thoroughly explained company policy as it pertained to your specific terms of employment? 69.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I signed a bunch of things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes or no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. I signed the contract. Yes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's our understanding that you were taken hostage in Iraq two hours ago, is that also correct?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. That's completely correct. What is the point of all this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alan breaks from the H.R. handbook script, though his ton remains just as matter-of-fact. The flashlight continues steady, slow dim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our legal department requires that we obtain a sworn affidavit from employees, confirming that they understand the reasons for their forced separation from the company. As of this morning, your employment with CRT was officially terminated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait, wait, wait -- The flashlight dims even more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was brought to our attention that you were engaging in relations with a fellow CRT employee -- Pamela Gorham.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Wait --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stipulated in your contract was a fraternization clause, in which it was stated quite clearly that any relationship, be it romantic or sexual in nature, deemed inappropriate by CRT senior officials is grounds for immediate termination. 70.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We...we were just friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our records indicate differently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is bullshit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're also legally required to inform you that because you were technically no longer under the employ of CRT at the time of your abduction, we cannot be held accountable for any injury that may befall upon you after your official date and time of termination. Therefore, in your case, that includes this incident or any consequences that may result from it. Paul sees where Alan is going with this. He's thunderstru

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about my insurance money? My family will need that money...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Given that you were alive up until the time of your termination --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You son of a bitch. You can't do this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you understand everything --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't do this! Alan takes a second before trying again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you understand everything you've been told, Mister Conroy? Paul does not answer.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN DAVENPORT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mister Conroy? 71.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After a long beat:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go to hell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That concludes our interview with Paul Conroy. I am now turning off the recorder. A click is heard. The humming ceases.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You people can't just wash your hands of this. You bastards put me here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. Alan ends the call. Paul looks at the phone -- it is still holding a steady signal. Battery life, however, is running quite low. All that remains is one blinking bar, indicating that Paul ha very little battery life left. He shakes his hand free of the pile of sand that now cove it and looks at his watch. It's 8:31pm. The flashlight bulb dims until it goes out completely. On the light of the cell phone display lights the coffin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wasting little time, Paul dials Jabir. The phone rings an rings, but Jabir does not answer. Checking to make sure t he dialed the correct number, Paul matches it against the phone number he wrote onto the wall of the coffin. Seeing that he did, in fact, dial correctly, Paul again t to call Jabir. While he waits through the many rings, he tries relighting the Zippo. Spark...spark...it catches. No one answers. Paul's disquietude is evident in his increasingly erratic behavior.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Answer the phone!! Paul tries Jabir once again, but still he does not answer phone. 72.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (desperate, exhausted) Why won't you answer?!! It's then that something occurs to Paul. He stares at the crack in the top of the coffin and the sand that pours in an alarmingly fast rate. The crack has split Jabir's written phone number in half. The aerial bombing. He wonders how it may have affected Jabir and, consequently, his own chances of survival. He places his hand under the point from where the sand pours most, allowing it to collect on his palm and slip through fingers. The flickering Zippo flame tells of the diminished amount oxygen. Paul attempts to control his breathing, realizing full we that there are not many more breaths he will be able to t He then calls Dan Brenner. After a few rings, Brenner answers. Paul is surprisingly serene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul, is that you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you know that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three F-16s levelled parts of the city a few minutes ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. I felt it. Did they know I was here? The Zippo flame flutters. Weakens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a beat) Yeah. 73.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did they care? Dan does not answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These people that took me -- if they're dead, they can't tell you where I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can still try to track down your signal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You tried that already.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can try again. Paul appreciates Dan's effort, but he knows there is litt hope left for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's over, isn't it? After a long beat:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Paul doesn't say a word. He knows that Dan is lying. Afte a beat, Dan comes clean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The flame of the Zippo becomes smaller. It clearly has little life left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What should I do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right -- just like everyone else on the planet, there are some things you know and some things you don't. 74.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish this could have gone differently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah...me too. After a long beat, Paul ends the call. He forces a smile his lachrymose face. Utterly hopeless, he opens the phone and turns on the vid feature. He turns the phone to face himself, projecting h image on the display. He presses Record.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Paul Steven Conroy. Social Security number 048-32-1198, date of birth 3/19/68. This video will serve as my last will and testament. To my wife, Linda Conroy, I leave the seven hundred dollars in my personal savings and whatever I have left in my annuity. To my son, Shane Conroy, I...I don't know. I don't have anything else. My stuff, like, my clothes. I wish I had more...I wish I had done more. Your dad wasn't really much of anything, Shane, I'm sorry. Maybe if I was a famous baseball player, or a guy who wore a suit to work, I would have more to leave you. But, you can be one of those people if you want. You can be whatever you want. Just promise me that when you get older, you'll take good care of your mom. And promise me that you'll always try to do the right thing, no matter what. I love you very much, Shane. Maybe I never said that enough...maybe I did, I don't even know. That probably means I didn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Linda. I should have listened to you. Paul ends the video and closes the phone. He carefully places the phone into his pocket, where it may hopefully found if he ever is. 75.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lays back, staring at the almost completely extinguish Zippo flame, as the sand continues to rain on him. Down and down it pours, the sands of time passing might a main through the cracks. The Zippo flame goes out. Paul sits in the darkness, resigned to what apparently will be his fate. Hold on black for several seconds...until -- -- suddenly, from inside Paul's pocket, he hears a faint vibration. It's the cell phone. He looks at the number of who is calling him. Shines the light of the cell phone on the list of numbers written on the top of the coffin. He can't believe what he's seeing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul answers immediately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not dead. Jabir is heard speaking frantically in Arabic to the seve other people in the room with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello? Hello?! Jabir turns his attention to Paul.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is money?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What don't know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know where the money is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Liar!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not lying! I swear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Swear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm telling the truth. 76.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sounding panicked, Jabir again speaks in Arabic to the ot people in the room with him. They respond accordingly. Paul tries to turn on the flashlight. It doesn't work. Jabir returns his scornful attention to Paul.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From Embassy, you get money now!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You will!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need more time. Please. Paul shakes and hits the flashlight. It still does not wo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No more time!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's sand pouring in here. I can't...it's everywhere. Please, let me out of here and I will get you the money. Jabir utters something in Arabic to someone standing next him, seemingly asking a question and getting an answer fr the same individual. Paul unscrews the top of the flashlight. Switches the positioning of the batteries. Screws the cap back on. Hit the switch. Nothing. Jabir returns to the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You show blood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? Paul unscrews the top of the flashlight again. Removes th batteries. Bites down on them a few times. Blows hard inside the flashlight tube.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You show blood, they give money. 77.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You cut off thumb finger, send video.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not doing that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes! Paul puts the batteries back inside the flashlight. Begin screwing on the cap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right, no. You let me out of here, and I'll cut off my whole God damn hand if you want. Jabir again says something to someone in the room with hi returning to Paul after a brief moment. Paul finishes closing the top of the flashlight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have wife? Click. The flashlight turns on!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul considers Jabir's question to be a potential sign of compassion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I do. And a son. A young son. I want to go home...to see them. Please, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Sir. I say that out of respect...to you. 78.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 243 East Walnut Street. Hastings, Michigan. U.S.A.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's my...why did you say that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You show blood...or they show blood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's...you're lying. You're nobody...all of you. You can't get to them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. You're peasants, criminals, that's all. You don't even know where Michigan is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Detroit. Ann Arbor. Even this basic knowledge is enough to make Jabir's threa that much more real.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You looked at a map. That's all you did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You show blood, or they show blood. Send video by five minutes. Jabir ends the call. Realizing that Jabir is gone, Paul quickly dials his wife's cell phone. After several rings, her voice mail picks up.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Hi, this is Linda. Please leave a message. Thanks and have a great day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Linda, listen to me: you and Shane have to go somewhere... anywhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't stay at the house, whatever you do, do not stay at the house. The guy...the kidnapper, he knows our address. He stole my license and now he knows where we live. Go to the Sheriff's station if you have to, just don't go home. Paul hangs up. He takes a moment to look around, noticing that the coffin is almost halfway filled with sand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (re: the sand) Holy God. Paul then dials Dan Brenner. After only one ring, the cal goes directly to voice mail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The flashlight starts to dim. Paul shakes it, causing it regain its strength.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Daniel Brenner. Please leave a message at the tone. The beep sounds. Paul delivers a frenzied message.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brenner, where are you?! He's alive! He just called me! Call me right away! The fucking guy is still alive! Paul hangs up the phone. Unsure what to do next, Paul's heartbeat races. He fidget nervously shaking and tapping his thumb against the phone He questions the validity of Jabir's threats toward his family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They can't find them. They...can't. There's no way. Paul opens the phone and brings up the photo of Pamela, b and gagged. The image causes Paul to second guess himself The flashlight goes out. The cell phone's display illuminates Paul's face. 80.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He then replays the video in which Pamela is seen being s Reliving the experience is extremely painful, though his concern is more on his own family at this point. However, the video is enough to convince Paul of Jabir and his cohort's convictions. Paul tries the Zippo. Nothing. Only sparks. He tosses it aside. His breathing grows erratic and labored. His eyes dart fr side-to-side, his throat groans involuntary noises of fea Paul then looks at the knife, and then at his watch. He h less than two minutes to send the video to Jabir. Fearing for the safety of his family, he must meet Jabir' demands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hits the flashlight a few times. Click. It turns on. Paul opens the phone and sets it to take video. He places flat onto the surface of the sand, which by this point is already filling the coffin halfway. He then reaches for t knife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my God. Oh my God. He places his hands against the side of the coffin, sprea his fingers. He stares intently at his thumb. With the extremely sharp knife in hand, Paul slowly lower just above his thumb. He inhales and exhales deep breaths almost hyperventilating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holy shit. Paul then reaches into the sand and finds one of the expi glow sticks. He shakes the sand off of it and places it across his mouth, biting into it hard. His heart races, his breaths are the deepest he's ever ta After placing the flashlight on the ground, to ensure tha the camera picks up the image, he presses the record butt on the cell phone. Grinding his teeth into the glow stick and letting out a primordial scream, Paul closes his eyes and chops down wi the knife. We see, through the display screen of the phone, Paul sev his thumb with a swift chop of the blade. 81.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small spray of blood spatters onto his face as he screa out in unfathomable pain. He falls to his side, still screaming and writhing. He reaches for his discarded outer-shirt, which is still stu in the crack to help slow the influx of sand. Removing th shirt from the crack instantly causes the sand to fall in the coffin more rapidly. Paul wraps the shirt around his hand. The blood quickly s right through it. He is fading fast. His blood loss is great. Shock sets in He musters up the strength to send the video to Jabir. To secure his shirt over the wound, Paul removes his belt from his waist and pulls it tight over his wrap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Growing increasingly more pale, Paul teeters on the verge consciousness. Everything becomes blurry to him. The phone falls from his hand. He shivers. His lips turn light shade of purple and his face ash white. Everything becomes more and more blurry. He fights with every last ounce of strength to remain conscious. While laying against the side of the coffin, the phone vibrates once again. To Paul, the vibration against the w seems so distant, so foreign. The vibration grows louder louder in his mind, sounding more and more like the sound rotating helicopter blades. He then hears what sounds like VOICES, yelling from on to the coffin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's down here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get him out! Keep digging!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul, we're here! The cacophony of voices form a mosaic of sound in Paul's head, each overlapping the other in distant echoes. Shove digging deep into the ground, are heard banging against t top of the coffin. The top of the coffin is torn open, sending a brilliant r of white light onto Paul. He stares into the light, cryin eking out a tortured smile. 82.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly, Paul is back in the same predicament. The voice the shovels, the light -- it was all a hallucination, bro upon by his loss of blood. He's still alone. He's still in the coffin, which continu to fill up with sand. He is too exhausted to display his disappointment. The phone continues to vibrate. It soon stops. Paul is in too poor condition to show any concern. After a beat, the phone begins vibrating once again. Afte several rings, Paul languidly picks it up. He barely recognizes the number through his extremely blurred visio He's so weak, he's barely able to formulate words. He spi out stray particles of sand from his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul, it's Brenner. Paul doesn't have the strength to answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul? Are you there? Paul?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm...here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're coming for you now. You hear me? We know where you are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This news serves as somewhat of an adrenaline rush for Pa who musters up even the modicum of strength he seemingly not have left in him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're coming?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are, Paul. We're almost there now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coalition forces picked up a Shiite insurgent just outside of Baghdad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Said he knew where an American was buried alive. He agreed to show us where if we let him go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're coming for me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're practically there already. An impossible smile fights its way to Paul's lips. His momentary joy is just that, however, for the sand has alm completely filled the coffin by this point.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have to hurry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No...you have to hurry. The sand...it's filling up fast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just hang in there for three more minutes. This will all be over soon, I promise. Paul is very hopeful that Dan is correct in his assumptio

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. I believe you. Thank you. Thank you. A beep is heard. Paul has another call coming in. He's visibly elated upon seeing who it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three minutes. Try to --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to go!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul, no --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call me right back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul! 84.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call me right back. Paul switches to the other call, despite the fact that he a mere eight inches left before the entire coffin is fill with sand from top-to-bottom. He holds the flashlight just above the top of the sand pi allowing it to illuminate what little unoccupied area remains.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Linda. Linda is in hysterics, which is evident in her speech.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul? Paul is that you? Tell me it's you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's me, sweetie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my God, Paul! What are they doing to you? Please tell me you're okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm...okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just saw the news. What...oh my God, baby. The flashlight dims. Paul shakes it, regaining a bit of i strength.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's going to be okay now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I missed all your calls. I left my cell phone at home. I just found out what was going on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's okay. It's all okay. They're getting me out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who? 85.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The people. Americans. They found out where I am and they're on their way to get me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are? Oh thank God. Oh dear God, thank you. The flashlight flickers. Paul hits it. It flickers some more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all going to be okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you know for sure? Oh God, please tell me you're okay. The flashlight continues to flicker almost like a stroboscopic light from this point forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was so afraid I was going to lose you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not. Linda breaks down in joyous tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you so much. I love you so, so much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I should have listened to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It doesn't matter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should have never come here. You were right. I'm sorry. 86.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sweetie, I don't care. I just want you home. Please come home to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Swear it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will. I swear I will. Paul then receives a call on the other line. He checks to see who's calling. It's Dan Brenner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The people?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're calling me right now. I have to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call me right away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will. I love you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you. Swear it again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I swear. I have to go. Paul clicks over to the other line, where Dan Brenner wai to speak with him. We hear Dan yelling to people who are with him. A great d of commotion and action is heard through the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Move! Move! Let's go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brenner?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paul? Paul? 87.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're here! Dan yells to one of the soldiers who are with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Corporal, get your men over here! Dan gets back on the phone with Paul

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He brought us right to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the soldiers) Start digging! Let's go, let's go! The flashlight fades. Paul hits it, momentarily returning to full strength. Meanwhile, the sand inside the coffin has almost reached very top. It continues to pour in from the crack, seeming faster than ever. Paul struggles to keep his head above the sand, giving hi only a few inches between his face and the top of the cof

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have to hurry. It's almost full.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just hang in there!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hurry! Please!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the soldiers) Dig! Dig! Dig! Paul fights to keep his head above the sand. The flashlig dims.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't...are you close?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're almost there, Paul. We're almost there! (to the soldiers)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Faster!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're almost there. We're right above you. The level of sand grows even higher. Paul spits away fall sand that threatens to suffocate him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't hear you! Where are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're almost there. A SOLDIER is heard OFF-SCREEN in the b.g. of Dan's phone.

dialogues.speaker: SOLDIER, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: There it is!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the soldiers) Keep digging!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hurry! Please!!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see the coffin! Just hang in there!! Paul coughs out sand. He has a mere inch left above his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hurry! Where are you? I don't hear you? Please hurry!!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Soldier is again heard OFF-SCREEN in the b.g. Of Dan' phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's clear!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the soldier) Open it! Nondescript noise is heard through the phone, until it co to an abrupt stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my God. 89.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm so sorry, Paul.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Mark White. He brought us to Mark White. I'm -- We see the circled name of "MARK WHITE" written in capita letters on the top of the coffin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said...!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I know. I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm so sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!! No!! NO!!! The battery life on Paul's phone runs out, causing it to power down. The filament of the flashlight bulb burns out As it does, the sand finally consumes the coffin, filling completely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear Paul's muffled screams emanate through the sand, until we no longer hear them at all. FADE OUT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Paul. I'm so sorry.
